title: Revisiting the Role of Natural Language Code Comments in Code Translation
data:
M Gupta, A Meena, AR Choudhury, V Arya, S Bedathur- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
The advent of large language models (LLMs) has ushered in a new era in automated 
code translation across programming languages. Since most code-specific LLMs are 
pretrained on well-commented code from large repositories like GitHub, it is 
reasonable to hypothesize that natural language code comments could aid in 
improving translation quality. Despite their potential relevance, comments are largely 
absent from existing code translation benchmarks, rendering their impact on

title: Survey on Learning-based Dynamic Fault Localization: From Traditional Machine Learning to Large Language Models
data:
C Liu, Y Lei, H Xie, J Wang, Y Yu, D Lo- ACM Computing Surveys
Learning-based dynamic fault localization techniques play a crucial role in the field 
of software engineering. These techniques dynamically execute test cases to 
meticulously extract useful knowledge from the execution information in the program, 
with the aim of identifying fault locations by leveraging machine learning, deep 
learning, and large language models. Currently, there is already a flourishing body of 
research that is intensely focused on learning-based dynamic fault localization
Cites: Thanh Le-Cong, Ratnadira Widyasari, Chakkrit Tantithamthavorn

title: Combining Tests and Proofs for Better Software Verification
data:
L Huang, B Meyer, M Oriol- arXiv preprint arXiv:2601.16239, 2026
Test or prove? These two approaches to software verification have long been 
presented as opposites. One is dynamic, the other static: a test executes the 
program, a proof only analyzes the program text. A different perspective is emerging, 
in which testing and proving are complementary rather than competing techniques 
for producing software of verified quality. Work performed over the past few years 
and reviewed here develops this complementarity by taking advantage of Design by
Cites: More reliable test suites for dynamic APR by using counterexamples

title: AI builds, We Analyze: An Empirical Study of AI-Generated Build Code Quality
data:
A Ghammam, M Almukhtar- arXiv preprint arXiv:2601.16839, 2026
The rapid adoption of AI coding agents for software development has raised 
important questions about the quality and maintainability of the code they produce. 
While prior studies have examined AI-generated source code, the impact of AI 
coding agents on build systems-a critical yet understudied component of the software 
lifecycle-remains largely unexplored. This data mining challenge focuses on AIDev, 
the first large-scale, openly available dataset capturing agent-authored pull requests
Cites: Thanh Le-Cong, Ratnadira Widyasari, Chakkrit Tantithamthavorn

title: Cutting the Gordian Knot: Detecting Malicious PyPI Packages via a Knowledge-Mining Framework
data:
W Guo, C Liu, M Kang, Y Zhang, J Wu, Z Xu- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
The Python Package Index (PyPI) has become a target for malicious actors, yet 
existing detection tools generate false positive rates of 15-30%, incorrectly flagging 
one-third of legitimate packages as malicious. This problem arises because current 
tools rely on simple syntactic rules rather than semantic understanding, failing to 
distinguish between identical API calls serving legitimate versus malicious purposes. 
To address this challenge, we propose PyGuard, a knowledge-driven framework that
Cites: Detecting Python Malware in the Software Supply Chain with

title: Toward Agentic Software Project Management: A Vision and Roadmap
data:
LI Assalaarachchi, Z Masood, R Hoda, J Grundy- arXiv preprint arXiv:2601.16392, 2026
With the advent of agentic AI, Software Engineering is transforming to a new era 
dubbed Software Engineering 3.0. Software project management (SPM) must also 
evolve with such transformations to boost successful project completion, while 
keeping humans at the heart of it. Building on our preliminary ideas of" agentic SPM", 
and supporting literature, we present our vision of an" Agentic Project Manager (PM)" 
as a multi-agent system for SPM 3.0. They will work like a" junior project manager", or
Cites: Agentic AI Software Engineers: Programming with Trust

title: iRUC: Reducing Inter-Microservice Data Communication in Data-Intensive Systems via Unified Computation
data:
P Wang, R Liu, K Huang, X Du- IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering, 2026
In data-intensive microservice-based systems, frequent and large-scale inter-service 
communication poses a critical performance bottleneck, degrading throughput and 
escalating latency. Existing solutions exhibit notable limitations: microservice 
merging sacrifices loose coupling and system evolvability; resource-aware 
scheduling enhances communication efficiency but fails to reduce data volume; 
dynamic deployment reduces network distances while introducing compute-resource
Cites: AutoCodeRover: Autonomous program improvement

title: CombiSan: Unifying Software Sanitizers for Comprehensive Fuzzing
data:
M Marini, F Gorter, DC D'Elia, C Giuffrida
Modern C/C++ bug detection efforts heavily rely on fuzzing with software sanitizers. 
However, the most popular sanitizers have limited interoperability. As a result, 
developers often enable each sanitizer in isolation, if at all, requiring multiple runs. 
This sequential execution undermines performance and tests code in a non-uniform 
manner. In this paper, we present COMBISAN, a fuzzing-optimized sanitizer that 
simultaneously detects all the addressability, uninitialized memory, and other
Cites: Efficient Greybox Fuzzing to Detect Memory Errors

title: " How did you fix it?"-Developer's feelings and practices when debugging with large language models: An analysis of reddit discussions
data:
Y Hao - 2025
While there has been extensive research on software developers' debugging 
processes, as the use of large language models (LLMs) enters the field of software 
engineering, their impact on developers has not been fully explored. The aim of this 
thesis is to investigate how developers use LLMs for debugging, including what 
kinds of inputs developers provide to LLMs, the sentiments they express when 
discussing LLM-assisted debugging, how they perceive the usefulness of LLM tools
Cites: Automatic program repair

title: Rust Meets Linux: Lessons from an Evolving Experiment
data:
H Li, L Guo, Y Yang, S Wang, M Xu- ACM Transactions on Computer Systems
Linux, developed over the past three decades, has become the cornerstone of 
modern computing, serving as the foundation for a wide array of applications ranging 
from large-scale supercomputers to resource-constrained embedded devices. 
However, this infrastructure has long been plagued by memory and concurrency 
bugs, primarily due to the permissive nature of memory operations in the C 
language. The Rust-for-Linux (RFL) project offers a promising solution to address
Cites: A memory model sensitive checker for C#

title: Variability-Aware Detection and Repair of Compilation Errors Using Foundation Models in Configurable Systems
data:
R Gheyi, L Albuquerque, M Ribeiro, E Almeida- arXiv preprint arXiv, 2026
Modern software systems often rely on conditional compilation to support optional 
features and multiple deployment scenarios. In configurable systems, compilation 
errors may arise only under specific combinations of features, remaining hidden 
during development and testing. Such variability-induced errors are difficult to detect 
in practice, as traditional compilers analyze only a single configuration at a time, 
while existing variability-aware tools typically require complex setup and incur high
Cites: Automated Program Repair

title: BRIDGING Human Expertise and Generative AI in Software Quality: A Study on Code Smell Detection in Software Engineering Education
data:
N Pombo, C Cunha- 2025 IEEE International Conference on Teaching, 2025
Large language models (LLMs) transform software engineering by providing AI-
assisted coding, debugging, and software quality analysis. Integrated into tools such 
as ChatGPT and GitHub Copilot, these models assist in code generation, refactoring, 
and issue detection, improving developer productivity. However, AI still presents 
challenges such as confabulations, limited contextual understanding, and 
inconsistencies in code recommendations. This study examines the role of LLMs in
Cites: Automated Program Repair

title: Agentic AI for Software Development: Autonomous Agents in Requirements Engineering, Testing, and Deployment
data:
R Konda- International Journal of Emerging Research in, 2025
The maturation of agentic AI (autonomous large language model (LLM) agents with 
planning, tool-use, and memory) is a sea change in software engineering. In contrast 
to the earlier, AI-guided tools that just presented static suggestions or local 
completions, AGI AI possesses the capability of goal-directed multi-step reasoning 
across the entire SDLC. This is most obviously seen in three of the mission-critical 
applications: requirements engineering, testing, and deployment. Each of these
